text:
Hi guys, I'm Laura Vitale and on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen I'm going to show

you how to make an unbelievably good sausage
and broccoli rabe pasta pie, now this is something

I grew up eating, there are many versions
of this you can make it with spaghetti - which

I often do, but this particular one is just
an homage to my mother and it's so good let

me run you through the ingredients because
there are not many but they're all the right
ones.

You need some fresh broccoli rabe that I have
washed and chopped, you need some Italian

sausage without the sausage, this is bulk
Italian sausage, you need sharp provolone

and shredded parmiggiano reggiano, eggs, salt
and pepper, olive oil, some short cut pasta,

I like using ziti or penne, you need some
whole cloves of garlic that have been peeled

but left whole, you need some olive oil and
that is pretty much it.
It's really easy and so unbelievable.

I've got my oven preheated to 425F and I also
have some pasta water coming to a boil to
cook the pasta.

I am going to be making this in my ten inch
pan with high sides because that's the shape
of the pie basically.

I've got some olive oil in there getting nice
and hot, I'm going to add my sausage now like

I said this is bulk sausage, which basically
just means it has the casing removed, you

can buy it like this but if you can't find
it just get a few links of Italian sausage,
remove the casing and you're good to go.

I'm adding it to my hot skillet and breaking
it up as much as I can with my wooden spoon,

now let me talk to you really really quickly
about broccoli rabe, broccoli rabe is a bitter

green, I grew up eating it I love its bitterness,
if you don't love the bitterness you can remove

some of it by blanching it first, I don't
do that because I think that defeats the purpose

of broccoli rabe and if I don't like it bitter
I may as well use spinach or broccoli.

Now in this particular recipe, I don't like
broccoli and you can use spinach but spinach

does give out a lot of liquid and it doesn't
give me that same consistency in my pasta
pie, that's why I stick to my broccoli rabe.

I'm going to keep my eye on the sausage I
want it to cook completely, and I'm also going
to add the pasta to my boiling water.

Sausage fully cooked, setting that aside - in
the same pan, I just took the sausage out

with a slotted spoon and added a bit more
olive oil.

I'm going to add my garlic, I want that to
start sizzling up a little bit, I also added

my pasta to the salted boiling water, I want
that to cook for about 8 or 9 minutes or until

it's just about al dente, don't overcook it
because it's going to go into the oven for
a bit.
I'm just going to babysit my garlic.

Just want it to kind of turn a little bit
golden, but mainly just release its flavor
into the oil.
Looks good, smells even better!

Now I'm going to add my broccoli rabe, that's
a good sound.

And now all you do is you have to kind of
push the broccoli rabe to the bottom of the

pan, you want it to kind of be coated in the
oil and the garlic.

And then you just have to babysit this until
the broccoli rabe starts to kind of wilt a

little bit and then we'll add a tiny bit of
water to get it cooking but I want to keep

the heat on high because I want to cook this
quickly.

My broccoli rabe looks phenomenal, now what
I did is I added a little bit of water, about

a half a cup or so of water, and I cooked
it until it completely evaporated and it took
about five or six minutes.

Now I'm going to take these out onto a clean
plate and I'm going to get rid of the garlic

as well, you can leave it in if you want to
but I like the flavor I just don't want to

chomp down on it, it overpowers everything
else and I don't care for that.

So I'm just going to take the broccoli rabe
out, onto a clean plate then I'm going to

drain the pasta, rinse it under cold water
to stop it from cooking and then bring everything
together.

Alright, broccoli rabe cooked, sausage cooked,
my cheese, my drained pasta that I've cooled

under running water, and I'm good to go, now
what you need to do is, in the same pan, you

don't need to wash it or anything, I added
a little bit of olive oil, now take a pastry
brush, and make sure it can handle heat.

And you take that olive oil and you brush
it along the sides, because otherwise it will

stick and nobody wants their macaroni pie
to stick, because that would defeat the purpose
of being able to eat it.

All I have is about a little less than two
tablespoons of olive oil in here.

And let's get going, to my eggs, I'm going
to add a really good pinch of salt, lots of

black pepper, if I can get this thing - why
isn't this thing working for me?
Come on!
There you go.

Good amount of black pepper, and now just
whisk the eggs just want to make sure that
they're mixed well.

Alright, to the eggs, you're going to add
everything right in.

So, cooked pasta, cooked sausage, you can
add all of it or half of it - I say all of
it!
Because I want this to be full on deliciousness.

My broccoli rabe, which you know, the broccoli
rabe, there's not a whole lot of liquid that

comes out of it so I don't have to worry about
it changing the texture of my pie and my cheeses.

And now with a wooden spoon, you have to make
sure that everything is really really well

mixed because everything has to be coated
by that egg because it's what holds it all

together, it's almost like edible glue if
you will.

Ok, now my pan has been just heating over
about medium heat, and then you just take

all of this, add it to your pan, it's a lot
it makes a really big fat pie, right?

And then you just kind of have to wiggle this
around and kind of push it down like that.
See what I'm doing?

Just like that and then I'm going to let this
cook on the stove here for about five minutes,

and then after the five minutes I'm going
to transfer it into the oven and it'll stay

in there for 45 to 45 minutes or until it's
a really deep golden brown color, and then

I'm going to let it come to room temperature
just a little bit before we serve it.
How gorgeous is this?

Now this was in the oven for 45 minutes, I've
let it come to room temperature because this

is really best eaten at room temperature,
or even better, cold out of the fridge.
The best!
So this is how you get it out:

It kind of loosens itself from the sides of
the pan, I take a plate, one - two.
Three.

That's why it's also important to wait until
it's at room temperature.
Look how beautiful!
I mean, am I right or am I right?

And then I just kind of flip it onto my serving
platter.

And look at that beautiful - I mean, if I
were a dish, I wouldn't want to be a lean

mean chicken breast, I would want to be a
gloriously bronzed, lovely and thick spicy
pasta pie.
That would be what I would be if I was a dish.
And I just had a papa Sal accent.
I don't know why.

I'm going to just go right for a big slice
right here.
Let's just...
I know!
I know!!
I know.
But, do I need to say anything?
It's perfection.
It's everything you want in food.

It's easy, quick, simple, easy basic ingredients,
the most comforting thing.
mmm!
Go get the recipe.

I'm done, go to LauraintheKitchen.com for
